ITEM 1. BUSINESS.summary:
Here are the key facts extracted from PART I - ITEM 1. BUSINESS section as bullet points:

• PLTR was founded in 2003.
• The company started building software for the intelligence community in the United States to assist in counterterrorism investigations and operations.
• Palantir has built four principal software platforms: Gotham, Foundry, Apollo, and AIP.
• Gotham has surfaced insights for global defense agencies, the intelligence community, disaster relief organizations, and beyond since 2013 (over a decade).
• Foundry is becoming a central operating system for individual institutions and entire industries.
• Apollo was offered as a commercial solution in 2021 and allows customers to run their software in virtually any environment.
• In 2023, Palantir began deploying its newest offering, AIP, designed for customers across the commercial and government sectors.

ITEM 1A. RISK FACTORS.summary:
Here are the key facts extracted from the PART I - ITEM 1A. RISK FACTORS section in bullet points:

• Until recent quarters, PLTR had a history of incurring net losses.
• PLTR anticipates its operating expenses will continue to increase and may not be able to maintain profitability in the future.
• A limited number of customers account for a substantial portion of PLTR's revenue.
• The market for PLTR's platforms and services may develop more slowly than expected.
• Issues raised by the use of AI (including machine learning and large language models) in PLTR's platforms and business may result in reputational harm or liability.
• PLTR depends on computing infrastructure of third parties, which may experience errors, disruption, performance problems, or failure.

Item 7. Management’s Discussion and Anal.summary:
Here are the key facts extracted from PART I - Item 7. Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Overview—Total Remaining Deal Value in bullet points:

• Total remaining deal value as of December 31, 2024: $5.4 billion
• Remaining deal value with commercial customers: $3.1 billion
• Remaining deal value with government customers: $2.3 billion

Here are the key facts extracted from the section in bullet points:

• The company relies on third-party services, software, and hardware to deliver its platforms and services, which can lead to errors or defects if these services fail or become unavailable.

• Disruptions, failures, data loss, corruption, unavailability, outages, and other performance problems with infrastructure or cloud-based offerings can occur due to various factors, including human or software errors, employee misconduct, capacity constraints, denial of service attacks, phishing attacks, computer viruses, ransomware, and cybersecurity threats.

• The company's systems and third-party systems are vulnerable to damage or interruption from catastrophic occurrences such as earthquakes, floods, fires, power loss, telecommunication failures, cybersecurity threats, terrorist attacks, natural disasters, public health crises, geopolitical tensions, and acts of misconduct.

• The San Francisco Bay Area, where the company has business operations, is a seismically active region, increasing the risk of physical damage to hosting facilities that could disrupt business operations.

• Disruptions or failures can result in errors or defects in platforms, cause revenue and margins to decline, damage reputation and brand, increase legal or contractual liability, and impair processes for managing sales and servicing customers.

ITEM 1C. CYBERSECURITY.summary:
Here are the key facts from PART I - ITEM 1C. CYBERSECURITY section in bullet points:

• Palantir maintains a security organization responsible for overseeing security practices across the Company.
• The Chief Information Security Officer leads the information security team and works with various departments to assess and review risks.
• Regular assessments and reviews are conducted on Palantir's information assets and networks, including systems, devices, applications, and related computing resources.
• Risk management exercises occur regularly, using techniques such as threat modeling, risk forecasting, and other methods to identify where investments in security should be made.
• Internal assessments are based on results from risk management exercises, changes in infrastructure, cybersecurity risks, and threat actor activity.
• External assessments are conducted by independent assessors, consultants, or auditors, occurring regularly to maintain certifications and accreditations with compliance regimes (e.g., FedRAMP).
• Palantir provides employees with policies and training on areas such as ethics, corruption, information security, social engineering, data protection, and compliance.
• The Company utilizes third-party software, services, and providers in its cybersecurity program, including endpoint security, threat intelligence, cloud security, and authentication services.
• Third-party vendors are required to implement industry standard technical, administrative, cybersecurity, and physical measures to protect Palantir information.

Item 1A. “Risk Factors”.summary:
Here are the key facts extracted from the "Risk Factors" section as bullet points:

• The company faces risks related to intellectual property, information technology, data privacy, and security.
• The Board of Directors has responsibility for the oversight of risk management, with its committees assisting in this role.
• The Chief Information Security Officer (CISO) oversees the cybersecurity program, policies, and processes.
• The CISO provides periodic briefings to the Board of Directors on cybersecurity risks and activities.
• The company's current CISO has over 15 years of experience in systems engineering and technical cybersecurity.
• The CISO holds a graduate degree in business administration and certifications in information security.
• The information security team includes employees with broad ranging experience in cybersecurity threat assessments, detection, incident response, and mitigation.

ITEM 2. PROPERTIES.summary:
Here are the key facts from PART I - ITEM 2. PROPERTIES section in bullet points:

• PLTR has leased principal properties in the following locations: 
  Denver, Colorado
  Palo Alto, California
  New York City, New York
  Washington, D.C.
  London, England

ITEM 3. LEGAL PROCEEDINGS.summary:
Here are the key facts from PART I - ITEM 3. LEGAL PROCEEDINGS section of PLTR's Annual Report:

• The company is subject to legal proceedings and claims arising in the ordinary course of business.
• The amount or range of reasonably possible losses will not, either individually or in the aggregate, have a material adverse effect on the company's business, results of operations, or financial condition.
• Defense and settlement costs, diversion of management resources, and other factors can have an adverse impact on the company regardless of the outcome of litigation.

ITEM 5. MARKET FOR REGISTRANT’S COMMON E.summary:
Here are the key facts extracted from PART II - ITEM 5. MARKET FOR REGISTRANT’S COMMON EQUITY, RELATED STOCKHOLDER MATTERS, AND ISSUER PURCHASES OF EQUITY SECURITIES in bullet points:

• As of February 10, 2025, there were 1,678 holders of record of PLTR's Class A common stock, 22 holders of record of Class B common stock, and one holder of record of Class F common stock.

• The company has never declared or paid any cash dividends on its capital stock and intends to retain future earnings without paying dividends in the foreseeable future.

• The Share Repurchase Program allows for the repurchase of up to $1.0 billion of PLTR's outstanding shares of Class A common stock, which was authorized by the Board of Directors in August 2023.

• During the year ended December 31, 2024, the company repurchased 2,123,131 shares of its Class A common stock under the Share Repurchase Program.

• The cumulative total return to stockholders on PLTR's Class A common stock since September 30, 2020, is compared to the cumulative total returns of the Standard & Poor’s 500 Index and the Standard & Poor’s Information Technology Index.

ITEM 7. MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANAL.summary:
Here are the key facts from the MANAGEMENT’S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS section in bullet points:

• The company was founded in 2003 and started building software for the intelligence community in the United States to assist in counterterrorism investigations and operations.
• The company has built four principal software platforms: Gotham, Foundry, Apollo, and Artificial Intelligence Platform (AIP).
• Gotham has surfaced insights for global defense agencies, the intelligence community, disaster relief organizations, and beyond for over a decade.
• Foundry is becoming a central operating system not only for individual institutions but also for entire industries.
• Apollo was offered as a commercial solution in 2021 and allows customers to run their software in virtually any environment.
• AIP was deployed in 2023 and enables customers across the commercial and government sectors to derive value from recent breakthroughs in artificial intelligence.
• The company is working to identify additional component parts and products embedded within its platforms that have potential as commercial offerings on their own.

Item 1A. Risk Factors”.summary:
Here are the key facts extracted from the PART II - Item 1A. Risk Factors” section in bullet points:

• As of December 31, 2024, the total remaining deal value of contracts with customers was $5.4 billion, up 40% from December 31, 2023.
• The total remaining deal value of commercial customer contracts was $3.1 billion, up 47% from December 31, 2023.
• The total remaining deal value of government agency contracts in the US and allied countries was $2.3 billion, up 30% from December 31, 2023.
• IDIQ contracts totaling $3.7 billion were awarded by government agencies but have not yet been funded or guaranteed as of December 31, 2024.
• Many government and commercial contracts are subject to termination for convenience provisions.
• The US federal government is prohibited from exercising contract options more than one year in advance.

ITEM 7A. QUANTITATIVE AND QUALITATIVE DI.summary:
Here are the key facts extracted from PART II - ITEM 7A. QUANTITATIVE AND QUALITATIVE DISCLOSURES ABOUT MARKET RISK in bullet points:

• As of December 31, 2024, PLTR held publicly-traded equity securities valued at $20.8 million.

• The fair value of these equity securities may fluctuate depending on the financial outcome and prospects of their issuers, as well as global market conditions.

• As of December 31, 2024, PLTR held privately-held equity securities valued at $64.9 million.

• Valuations of these private equity holdings are complex due to lack of liquidity and readily available market data.

• The company's cash, cash equivalents, restricted cash, and available-for-sale debt securities consist of cash, short-term U.S. Treasury securities, money market funds, and certificates of deposit.

• Due to the short-term nature of these financial instruments, PLTR has not been exposed to material risks due to changes in interest rates.

• The company's contracts with customers are primarily denominated in U.S. dollars, with remaining amounts denominated in foreign currencies (JPY, Euro, GBP).

• Fluctuations in net income (loss) may occur as a result of transaction gains or losses related to remeasuring certain asset and liability balances denominated in foreign currencies.

• To date, foreign currency transaction gains and losses have not been material to PLTR's consolidated financial statements.

ITEM 8. FINANCIAL STATEMENTS AND SUPPLEM.summary:
Here are the key facts from PART II - ITEM 8. FINANCIAL STATEMENTS AND SUPPLEMENTARY DATA section, formatted as bullet points:

• The consolidated financial statements of Palantir Technologies Inc. were audited by Ernst & Young LLP.
• The audit was conducted in accordance with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles (GAAP).
• The auditor expressed an unqualified opinion on the Company's internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2024.
• The auditor's report was dated February 18, 2025.
• The auditor has served as Palantir Technologies Inc.'s auditor since 2008.

ITEM 9A. CONTROLS AND PROCEDURES.summary:
Here are the key facts from PART II - ITEM 9A. CONTROLS AND PROCEDURES section of PLTR's Annual Report on Form 10-K, formatted as bullet points:

• The company's disclosure controls and procedures are designed to ensure timely and accurate reporting of required information.
• As of December 31, 2024, the Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer concluded that the company's disclosure controls and procedures were effective at a reasonable assurance level.
• The company's management is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting.
• Based on an evaluation conducted under the 2013 framework, the company's internal control over financial reporting was effective as of December 31, 2024.
• Ernst & Young LLP issued an audit report with respect to the company's internal control over financial reporting, which is included in Part II, Item 8, "Financial Statements and Supplementary Data".
• There were no changes in the company's internal control over financial reporting identified during the period covered by this Annual Report on Form 10-K that have materially affected or are reasonably likely to affect the company's internal control over financial reporting.
• The effectiveness of any system of internal control over financial reporting, including the company's, is subject to inherent limitations and can only provide reasonable assurance of achieving control objectives.

ITEM 9B. OTHER INFORMATION.summary:
Here are the key facts extracted from PART II - ITEM 9B. OTHER INFORMATION in bullet points:

• Alexander Moore adopted a Rule 10b5-1 trading arrangement on November 22, 2024, with a maximum of 240,000 shares subject to conditions.
• The duration of the trading arrangement is until February 27, 2026, or earlier upon completion/expiration of all transactions.
• Alexander Karp terminated his previous Rule 10b5-1 trading arrangement on November 22, 2024.
• Karp adopted a new Rule 10b5-1 trading arrangement on December 11, 2024, with a maximum of 9,975,000 shares subject to conditions.
• The duration of this new arrangement is until September 12, 2025, or earlier upon completion/expiration of all transactions.
• Stephen Cohen adopted a Rule 10b5-1 trading arrangement on December 11, 2024, with a maximum of 4,060,000 shares subject to conditions.
• The duration of this arrangement is also until September 12, 2025, or earlier upon completion/expiration of all transactions.

ITEM 10. DIRECTORS, EXECUTIVE OFFICERS A.summary:
Here are the key facts from PART III - ITEM 10. DIRECTORS, EXECUTIVE OFFICERS AND CORPORATE GOVERNANCE in bullet points:

• The Proxy Statement for the 2025 Annual Meeting of Stockholders will be filed with the SEC within 120 days of the fiscal year ended December 31, 2024.
• Palantir's Board of Directors has adopted a code of conduct that applies to all employees, officers, and directors, including executive and senior financial officers.
• The full text of Palantir's code of conduct is posted on its investor relations page at https://investors.palantir.com.
• Palantir has an Insider Trading Policy governing the purchase, sale, and other dispositions of its securities, which applies to all officers, directors, and employees.
• A copy of Palantir's Insider Trading Policy is filed as Exhibit 19.1 to this report.

ITEM 15. EXHIBITS AND FINANCIAL STATEMEN.summary:
Here are the key facts from PART IV - ITEM 15. EXHIBITS AND FINANCIAL STATEMENT SCHEDULES:

• The company has filed the following documents as part of this Annual Report on Form 10-K: Financial Statements and Financial Statement Schedules.
• Exhibits listed include those filed "Herewith" or incorporated by reference, with some certifications excluded from filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
• The certifications attached as Exhibit 32.1 are not deemed filed with the SEC and should not be incorporated into any future filings.
